item.description:
A new of its kind strategy board game for 2 to 6 players. Take your viruses and battle your opponent's occupied cells, but be careful, the cure syringe is also part of the game. Take risks and dominate the game. Challenge your friends and let them Infected.

Featuring built-in neodymium magnet characters and fully magnetized board.

Play Infected in single mode or in team mode with your friends. 
Each player takes at the role of one color virus and battles his opponent's occupied cells with the purpose of infecting other player's head viruses to win the game. Avoid the cure miracles, make the right moves to infect cells, take risks and dominate the game. Let your friends Infected.

Infected: The Board Game is not like other games. Here, players don't start in the same place each game played. Infected randomize the way to start each game by spinning the Infected spinning disk and throwing the dice at the beginning of the game.

All viruses start in each player's head virus, so protecting your head virus is something to always keep in mind.

A great art exhibition is celebrated. For the first time it has managed to gather in a great exhibition numerous objects, jewels and artworks that until now it had not been possible to contemplate together. This exhibition is assembled for the first time in a museum enabled in The Alhambra Palace (Seville, Spain). Incredible safety deployment, protection systems have been carefully designed.

Among all the pieces featured are five valuable jewels coveted by the world's most famous thieves, who will meet there in an attempt to prove who is the best of them all. They will all try to steal them without being trapped.

No one can enter without jumping the system. No one? ... Nothing can be removed from the museum without being detected. Nothing?...

Penetrate into the Palace of the Alhambra, getting as many jewels as possible and escaping without being discovered is the challenge of the game. Each player becomes a thief for the duration of the game, and must use all his ingenuity to avoid escape the strict security measures that have been put in place to protect the jewels. All the tools and weapons necessary to carry out the stole have been buried in the Palace Gardens: the Arrayanes's Garden and the Lion's Garden, months before the Opening of the Exhibition, and so during the first tour for these two gardens, simulated to be innocent visitors, the players are collecting the necessary equipment.

The only escape route is through the Mosque located in the northwest corner of the Palace, as the Alhambra is surrounded by walls around its perimeter. There are a powerful off-road vehicle that will take the triumphant thief down the mountain with the precious booty.

If you get it, you will have won and the first pages of the international press will open their editions with "Scandal! Theft of the Century".

Goals of the Game:

The players decide when starting the game which game mode they will play:


 Win the first player to steal a jewel and escape.



 All jewelry must be stolen, and that player who gets the most value by adding the points of the jewels obtained is the one that wins. In case of a tie, the thief who holds the Recesvinto's Crown will win.

Bring the iconic 80’s slasher movie to life in this intense, immersive board game. The innovative story-board mechanism puts you in front of the camera as the scenes unfold, leading you and your fellow cast members through a terrifying night in a variable wilderness setting. Use cunning to survive until dawn or stand and fight to stop the Killer once and for all. Gather Plot Points to maintain your Courage in the face of horror as your Supporting Cast is slaughtered around you. Will you be able to reveal the Killer’s vulnerabilities and face him (or her) down before the mayhem of Act 3 begins? Or will you simply run for your life, never knowing where terror will strike next? Either way, the Story Board will track the choices you’ve made and tell your tale of woe (or heroism) to all who dare to watch the Silver Scream...

What did the tiger get as a great gift? And why did the penguin bring the same six gifts? Whoever can count the points correctly gets to unwrap the wacky gifts. Here we go! Throw the dice, count, receive gifts. A crazy game for 2-4 players ages 4-99 that helps develop counting and math skills!

Malaysianised card game based on the same engine as Cards against Humanity.

START
Choose a ‘Boss’ (the judge)
Boss deals all players 8 cards

MATCH
Boss displays and reads aloud a Yellow card
All players (except the Boss) match a Blue card within their hand to the Yellow card

BODEK
Players bodek (persuade) the Boss to choose their card
Boss picks a winner

A children's space themed board game played by moving playing pieces along numbered squares till they reach the moon. Starting from earth, the first to get to the moon is the winner. Along the way players will encounter picture squares which have either set back or speed up their travel.

Playing pieces are simple counters and the board has graphics very similar to the British Dan Dare space caricature. Published about 1957 by Emu Series in the U.K.

The purpose of this spin and move vintage space exploration game is to travel to as many planets as possible on the playing board starting at the rocket launching platform spot. The planets are located around the edge of a Monopoly style layout. Each player receives the celestial currency called Celestros upon visiting a planet. Players can encounter setbacks and benefits along the way by landing on specific squares. The game is over when all players return to the Launching Platform. The player with the greatest amount of currency wins the game.

The game has beautiful box graphics typical of the 50s era. The board has the spinner built into it and the playing pieces are colored plastic rockets very similar to that produced by the Lido corporation and seen in the board game Rocket Race to Saturn (1953). Rules are printed on the inside of the box lid and the game was produced by the E-Z game Manufacturing Corporation, New York. Another version of the game is all but identical except the title was changed to 'Race to Planets'.

name.value: Space: A Race to the Moon

item.description:
A roll and move electronic space race board game starting at the Woomera rocket range in Australia. The first to reach the moon is the winner. Two players each have a wired playing piece (electrode) that they move by the roll of the die. The electrode piece advances along small holes in the board towards the moon passing planets along the way. Each player has to follow a separate route to the moon made of these small holes. At certain contact points along the way the playing piece sets off one of a series a colored warning lights on the board that indicates a penalty sending them back to a planet. On reaching the moon a yellow light in the moons center indicates the winner.

Unknown publisher but most likely Australian or English considering the unique launch zone where rocket testing was conducted during the 1950s

A space exploration spinning top board game. The object of the game is to spin and steer four capsule travel tops into the solar system game board and attempt to land on planets to win points. To win, tally up all points to make the highest possible score.

Each player spins three yellow tops. The yellow capsule tops spins on the playing board and the player tilts the board to make the tops travel into the solar system and stop in a circular hole representing a planet and score points. This is repeated with one red top to score double points. Trouble if you land on the sun, either losing half your points if it was a yellow top or all points if your red capsule stops on the sun. The player having the highest score after spinning all four tops is the winner.

Description from the game insert:

During the same sitting, you can find yourself at the Casino, at the race, at an auction, or playing a friendly game of poker... all the while scratching cards to find out if you have a chance to win or if you have lost your bid. Scratshow starts with a roll of the dice telling you where your pawn will land. Are you on a Poker square? Take a scratch card marked Poker and discover your hand. Place your bet, bluff, raise... Your pawn takes you to the races? Place your bet, scratch a card and find out if your horse is in the Win, Place or Show category. The first player who gets to be a millionaire wins the game.

Description from the box insert:

A game where the scholar is not necessarily the winner. A game where wits provide for hilarity. The Great Dictionary Game is a fun-filled search for the definition of a word picked out of the dictionary and starting with one or more of the letters appearing on a card chosen at random. Proposed definitions can be absolutely accurate, a figment of the imagination, incoherent, plausible, misleading or humorous. The winner is the player with the highest score of points obtained either from his bets on accurate definitions or from votes of players.

Description from the publisher:

The B-26 has arrived in the European Theater of Operations. It has now joined the B-17, B-24 and the Lancaster over the skies of war torn Europe...

B-26: The Marauder Strikes! is a solitaire game set onboard a Martin B-26 Marauder medium bomber during World War Two in the European Theater of Operations from July 1943 until the end of the war in May 1945. It is a big game in that there are many target lists, rules, mission maps and details which are not found in B-17: Queen of the Skies or B-29 Superfortress: Bombers over Japan. For example, the Damage Tables are more detailed than the earlier games and the combat system is similar, but completely new. The Target Lists include a large selection of targets attacked by B-26s from July 1943 until the end of the war in May 1945 and are placed on 13 maps (Movement Boards) which are different depending on where your base is located, from England to the Netherlands. Different models of the B-26 is also included from the early B-26 in 1941 until the B-26G which entered combat in October 1944. The earlier models are not used in the European Theater of Operations (the ETO) in which B-26: The Marauder Strikes! is set, but will be used in 22nd Bomb Group: Marauders from Australia, an add-on variant set in the Pacific in the war against Japan in New Guinea.

The rules in this Flight Manual try to reflect the twin engine B-26 Marauder and situations and events which the crews saw on their missions and historical accuracy has been an important guideline during the development of this game.

Players familiar with B-17: Queen of the Skies or B-29 Superfortress: Bombers over Japan recognize the mechanics used in B-26. One or more 6-sided dice are rolled on tables to plan the mission, to determine if enemy fighters appear, to hit with machine gun fire and to determine damage and wounds and much more. B-26 is as easy to play as B-17 with its basic system which is similar to the mechanics in B-17: Queen of the Skies. Players who have flown missions in B-17 may find that B-26 is similar, but more detailed and there are ideas included in B-26 which can be found in the B-17: Queen of the Skies community. If you add the advanced and optional guidelines you will find B-26 to become deep, detailed and complex, but still does not stray far from the simple mechanics of the basic system. You will also find yourself in situations where you have to make a decision.

The Core Game Flight Manual will be used to play the A-20 Havoc, A-26 Invader and B-25 Mitchell add-ons.

You can begin your campaign flying missions from bases in England or jump in later in the war when the B-26 groups had moved to the continent and you will find Mission Maps with your station either in England, France, Belgium or the Netherlands depending on when you fly your missions. Put together a crew, name your B-26 and fly missions over France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia!

This cat is soooo moody! 
He'll switch from happy to angry in one step.

In this game you play as a mischievous alley spirit on a mission to earn silver feather points by affecting Moody Cat's mood as he's prancing down your alley. As a spirit you are forbidden to affect the cat’s mood directly so you'll have to enlist help from other creatures. Keep in mind that there are other alley spirits competing for the points and will try to outsmart you in their efforts to earn more points than you. So unleash your spirit power to meddle with the Moody Cat.

Typically played as a set number of game rounds with score keeping after each game. The winner is determined after the last game in a set.

Enter the magical workforce as a nomadic wizard, wandering the fields and valleys to complete spell jobs. What is the ultimate goal? The greatest reward of all: fame.

As one of these enterprising wizards in Wizards Wanted, you must gather magical experience and coins for your work. Resourcefulness is essential as you pick up helpful mushrooms, buy magical dust from tricky pixies, and navigate the twisted paths and teleportation stones. But don't meander too much. You need to be in good standing with the Royal Palace and earn your Spell License by the end of the game, so get to work!

item.description:
Congratulation ! you just made a burnout !
You wake up in a psychiatric hospital and doctor said "
No problem, in 30 years you go out".

The goal of the game is to make your imaginary friend guess as many words as possible within 40 seconds. Unfortunatly you take pills that restrict your language and your gestures. When it is again your team's turn, the player who made the patient becomes the imaginary friend but retains the effect of his pills. Guaranteed fun!

item.description:
2 players

Materials
A hex board having 37 cells, 4 hexes to a side, and 37 stones in a single color

Setup
Place a stone, in each of the 37 cells of the board

Definitions
Group - one or more adjacent stones

Object
The player with the most stones wins

Play
Choose a starting player, turns alternate

On a turn remove 2 non-adjacent stones from a line of adjacent stones.

Clarifications
Removed stones are used for endgame scoring

If a group is split into 2 or more groups, the player that caused the split takes the smallest group, but if the smallest groups are of equal size, the player then decides which one to take

Endgame
The game ends when a player cannot take his turn

Vanguard of War (VoW) is a 1-4 player game focused on the defense of a small church deep inside the decaying ruins of a once great city now known only as “the Whispers.” Players will use their heroes to hold the line against seemingly endless waves of demons while their allies inside the church desperately attempt to learn how to use the fel army's own doomsday weapon against them.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

In the Yahtzee-like dice game Dice'n Score! Farm, players get to throw the dice up to three times on their turn while attempting to make high-scoring sets of animals. Choose carefully which ones to score as each line of animals can be scored only once! If all the possible choices for a roll have been filled, then you must score zero points in another box of your choice.

If you score 18 or more points on the upper half of the score sheet, then you receive 10 bonus points. Roll five identical items, and you get a 10-point Big Farm bonus. Whoever has the highest score when all the score sheets are filled wins!

To win at Can't Stop Express, you need the courage to take risks, but also the ability to predict and plan. After each throw of the five dice, you try to choose the best combination of two pairs while also making a good choice for the fifth die. Through this effort, you are awarded points, and whoever has the most points at the end of the game — which usually takes 24-25 rolls — wins.

The instructions includes solitaire rules

item.description:
Using four cones, three scoops, two hands and one challenge card in Go Go Gelato!, you want to scoop your way to victory as quickly as you can.

To start the game, each player takes four cones (one of each color) and three scoops of gelato (in three of the four colors), then places those scoops in the matching cones. Someone reveals a challenge card, then everyone races to maneuver the right scoops into the right cones — all without dropping the scoops or touching them by hand. No one will want to eat that! Fulfill the order first, and you claim the challenge card. Whoever collects five challenge cards first wins!

item.description:
Can you grab the microbes you need?

In each round of Dr. Microbe, you're presented with a challenge card that shows some combination of microbes and (possibly) a superbug. Each player has tweezers and a petri dish that's divided into three small sections and one large one. As soon as the card is revealed, players must race to place the microbes (and superbug, if present) in their petri dish. What's more, they must figure out which microbes (and possibly the superbug) to place in their petri dish based on this rule: The superbug must always be a different shape and color than the other three microbes in your dish! Whoever fills their dish with the proper items first claims the challenge card, and whoever first grabs five cards wins the game!

As a variant, you can play with the purple virus, which starts the game in the large petri dish that contains all of the other bits. You can grab this purple virus and place it in the petri dish of your left-hand neighbor, then that person can pass it left, etc. You can't end the round if the purple virus is in your petri dish! Whoever has the purple virus in their dish at the end of the round must give one of their previously collected cards to that round's winner.

link.value: Blue Orange Games Mad Scientist Series

item.description: Sunk! is a skill and action game in which the task is to add water — one drop at a time — to the cup floating in the water-filled tank without causing it to sink. You're not simply pouring water, though, as the game involves challenge cards as well. Can you pour with only one eye open? What about when you're hopping on one foot?

Description from the publisher:

Nibbled is a fast-paced, easy-to-learn game that starts with kids clipping four plastic fish onto themselves. Guess a color, then flip a card. Guess correctly, and you unclip one fish and clip it onto an opponent. Whoever first unclips all of their fish wins!

An explosion of creativity and violence erupted in the Aegean Basin in 800 B.C. that defined ancient Greece. This combination of science, mythology, development, and war was led by powerful city-states like Athens, Sparta, Corinth, Troy, Byzantium, Corcyra, and Thebes. These states vied for control over their rivals and dominated the lesser states around them. In time, some of them became so well known that they are remembered even today.

Hellenica: Story of Greece is a 3.5X civilization game in which you harness the powers of one of seven beginning city-states to dominate the world around you. Your goal is to become the preeminent symbol of Greece for all posterity by completing a combination of secret and public goals. Will you be remembered as a warmonger or a peaceful philosopher? Great priest or apostate? Will you develop a devotion to the gods or focus on the advancement of your people?

Can you guide your civilization during these turbulent times? Will your vision of Hellenic civilization be remembered for all time, or will you merely be a stepping stone for another…?

name.value: The Lion Guard: Gut gebrüllt, Kion!

item.description:
From the publisher:

An exciting race with the heroes from the TV series "The Guard of the Lions".

The little lion Kion is leader of the "Guard the Lion", they protect the sacred land. From his vantage point on the King's Rock, Kion discovers some wandering hyenas, which always cause trouble. With loud roar, he calls his friends for help! Who will win the exciting race and be the first at Kion?

From the Publisher:

"I'm packing into my suitcase ..." - and the number of things being remembered is getting longer! Now two games in one: classic with travel luggage or even witty with crazy grimaces and movements!

"I pack in my suitcase ..." and the series of memorized things is getting longer. Now two games in one: classic with travel luggage or even witty with crazy grimaces and movements! 
The classic is even more fun now!

Description from the publisher:

It's time for a new leader to be selected by the gods to lead the nation. To help sway their decision, players must make offers to win their favor.

In Kronia, favor tokens are placed in three different temples, then players will make secret offers to these temples over the course of twelve rounds. Everyone starts with the same offer cards, so they must anticipate which Gods other players want to please. Deciding when to spend the more appealing offers and when to hold off can be the difference. In the end, the player with the most points from their favor tokens will be chosen to lead the nation into the future.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Monopoly, the legendary game of risk taking, deal making, and owning it all, and The University of Texas at Austin, the celebrated university of academics, research, and national championships, team up to create a classic board game for Longhorm fans everywhere. Take a spin around the board to find the best loved athletes, coaches, buildings and scenes of one of America's great universities. And be prepared to pay big bucks if you land on the Tower or Littlefield Fountain-the University's most recognized building and beloved spot on campus don't come cheap!

Grab your friends and family put on your Longhorn sweatshirt and enter the halls of UT at Austin for the game of your life. The Texas Union, Show Band of the Southwest, Darrell Royal, Littlefield Home or 99 other Longhom properties can all be yours. Whether a student, alumnus or fan, can you resist the chance to buy Texas' finest?

GAME INCLUDES: Game Board Property Cards. Play Money and Bankers Tray. 2 Dice 10 Game Tokens. Chance Cards Community Chest Cards Package of Houses. Package of Dormitories
Two monsters have escaped from the monster party! Let's go searching for them in Monster Wanted! If you can remember who vanished and who's still at the party, you could win the game.

name.value: Mauseschlau & Bärenstark Rund um die Natur

item.description:
From the publisher

A memorabilia and collecting game with mouse squeaky and bearish actions!

With Mauseschlau & Bärenstark It's in the nature! There the players learn local animals, flowers, tree and berry fruits. In addition, they can show how well they can represent animals and imitate animal voices. If you also show some skill in gyros and a good memory, the first to collect 6 picture cards and win

Description from the publisher:

You are a young Captain, in charge of your own fleet of ships, seeking fame and fortune.

In Commanders of Land and Sea you take the role of the Captain of a fleet of ships that seeks to expand its domain, your goal is to take over as many islands as possible, placing your boats in them, claiming their treasures and increasing your power; At the same time you must eliminate the other players, destroying their ships and taking possession of their main ports.

You have found an area of the ocean where there are several islands that are not under any kingdom or country, it is your duty to land on them and reclaim them along with their wealth as your own. But be careful, other corsairs, have also established themselves in nearby ports, and are also in search of new domains, you must face them and prove to them who is the most powerful, using your ships and wealth to eliminate their ships and drive them away.

What are you waiting? Have fun sailing your ships, conquering islands landing in their ports and increase your wealth; face your opponents and if necessary send them flying by exploding your traps. Who will be the most successful Captain? You will have to play to find out.

Eclectica is a word-based game for two or more players. Teams compete to decipher clues, get words, and phonetically rearrange them to find answers. The first team to identify the correct answer wins the point!â€‹â€‹

Clues are based on all subjects - ranging from art to mathematics to idioms in the English language - so there’s plenty of room for everyone to play!

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Charms is a fun, easy to learn party game where each player takes a turn as the Quester by asking a question from the Quest Cards (or their own question). Everyone else finds their inner sage and tries to write the wisest answer based on the Quester's roll of the charms, their meanings, and where they land on the board. The Quester then picks the winning answer. The player with the most winning answers wins the game.

Understand the game in 4 basic steps.

1. Draw a card, read a question to the group, and roll 9 random charms onto the board. Remove "out of play" charms.

2. Use the KEY CARD to review charm meanings. Other players quickly write an answer to your question based on the charms, where they landed on the board, and what this could mean for you.

3. The answers are read aloud. You pick the one that best answers your question, and the author is revealed as the winner of the round.

4. Pass the charms to the left and play again until everyone has asked a question. The player who writes the most winning answers is crowned the Charms Champion of Insight!

item.description:
Does the stupidest farmer have the biggest potatoes? Not in this game! This is because the clever cultivation of beds, which is about the meaningful juxtaposition (mixed culture, plant friendliness) and succession (fruit sequence), leads to a sumptuous harvest and thus to win the game.
Gameplay: Players systematically grow vegetables, fruit and herbs. They plant according to the garden calendar and promote the growth of their plants. However, a lot has to be taken into account. Are they low or flat rooted, weak, medium or heavy consuming? Does the plant have a long or short growth period? In addition, weather caprioles, beneficial insects and pests, the neighbor or other imponderables can influence the tranquil gardener life.
Game objective: The players try to "harvest" as many self-planted as also by other players placed plant cards. Whoever has the greatest harvest yields is the winner of the game.

Using the Napoleonic version of the March into Battle system, this game portrays the Battle of Quatre Bras in a furious, fast moving two turn game. Part of a group of mini-games on the battles of the Waterloo campaign, with Ligny and La Belle Alliance.

In this system as in reality, units will become ineffective from fatigue and disorder long before they run out of men - unless you, in command, can manage them effectively and maintain their edge. A turn lasts as long as the typical historical time to arrange and execute an assault - every move counts.

Map scale: 1km per hex
Unit scale: divisions, 1000 men per strength point
Time scale: 3.5 hours per turn

A solitaire, CDG-flavoured, strategic-level game set during the Marcomannic Wars, 170CE-180CE. Playing from the perspective of Emperor Marcus Aurelius, your goal is to defeat and pacify three different tribes while managing off-map wars and rebellions, troop shortages, limited resources, and the effects of plague—all while maintaining your standing with the Senate and people of Rome.

The Marcomannic Wars were a series of conflicts fought by the Romans against a loose coalition of German and Sarmatian tribes along the Danube from 166CE to 180CE. After crushing a Roman army and killing as many as 20,000 Roman soldiers near Carnuntum, German barbarians ravaged the Danube provinces and besieged Aquileia, marking the first time a hostile force had entered Italy in nearly 300 years. Meanwhile, Sarmatians invaded Dacia and Costoboci descended deep into the Balkans and Greece as far as Athens. It took Rome more than a decade to restore peace, with war and plague extracting a terrible cost of human and material resources.

The game covers the war from the disastrous Battle of Carnuntum in 170CE to Marcus Aurelius' death in 180CE. Each turn (lasting one year) is divided into four rounds: early campaign, late campaign, winter and an attrition/house keeping round.

At the start of each round, the player draws three barbarian cards and resolves their effects. Barbarian cards activate enemy tribes (restoring their morale or causing them to advance), trigger off-map conflicts, or cause special events such as plague, mutiny, or rebellions.

On their turn, the Roman player draws a set number of cards (5 during the early campaign, 3 during the late campaign, and 1 during winter) and plays as many or few as they choose for either actions or events. Actions include: attacking barbarian tribes; building forts; moving legions; and increasing "Imperium Points.” Many cards can also be played for historically based events, such as the "Lightning miracle" depicted on the Column of Marcus Aurelius; and the "Galen" event that mitigates the effects of plague. All cards must be used by the end of the year or discarded, except for one card that can be held over into the next year by use of the "Meditations" deck.

Battles are resolved by rolling 1d6 for the Romans and 1d6 for the Barbarians. The Roman role is modified by the number of legions assigned to the front and the combat rating of the leader. Cards can be spend to commit "reserves" to avoid a defeat or eek out a victory. Other cards including "Ambush," "Tactical Superiority" and "Route" can affect the outcome of battles. Enemy die rolls are modified by the morale of the tribe and the terrain, representing the barbarians' knowledge of the lands north of the Danube and Romans' difficulties in maintaining supply lines.

Players can lose in a number of ways: if the Marcomanni break through into Italy the game immediately ends. Suddenly death also occurs if the player's Imperium Points (IP) drop into "usurpation." If all three tribes have not been defeated and pacified by 180CE the game also ends in a loss.

The player wins by driving barbarians back into their home space and defeating them there. Once a tribe is defeated they must be kept pacified by building forts and keeping troops assigned to garrisons, or they may break their treaty and rejoin the fight (as happened historically). Final victory occurs if all three tribes have surrendered. The player's score takes into account the number of years that have elapsed, their IP level, and the number of off-map conflicts they have resolved.

In Sherlook, players examine two nearly identical images that have only minor differences between them. Everyone uses their powers of perception to determine how many anomalies there are before the other players can. The faster they can figure it out, the more points they earn — assuming they're right!

Sherlook contains forty images, each with only slight differences from one another, so that players can return to the scene of the crime again and again.

item.description: In Contact, players take turns as the Spy whose goal is to keep their chosen word secret. They reveal the first letter of their secret word to begin the round. Other players take turns interrogating/asking a question of the Spy who must truthfully answer, thus revealing what the secret word is not in the process. Their answers must also begin with the revealed letter(s). If a question stumps the Spy the other players may Contact the Interrogator to provide their answer. If the answers are the same then the Spy reveals the next letter in their secret word, thus making it harder to keep their word secret.

An stand alone expansion to Monikers that is comprised of cards relating to podcasts hosted by Justin, Griffin, and Travis McElroy. These shows include My Brother, My Brother, and Me; The Adventure Zone; Rose Buddies; Shmanners; and Sawbones. It's a limited edition expansion that may only be available through preorders.

From the publisher's website
The McElroy brothers present a standalone expansion for the inexplicably popular party game Monikers. They've created 112 new cards — all drawn from characters, goofs, and weird asides from the McElroy family shows: My Brother My Brother and Me, The Adventure Zone, Sawbones, Shmanners, and more.

name.value: 1831 For our freedom and yours: Battle of Grochow

item.description:
Board wargame 1831 For our freedom and yours: Battle of Grochow represents one of the most famous battles in the history of the Polish army. Players have historical forces and must act, given the historical advantages and limitations of their armies. Also important are factors such as terrain and weather conditions. Of course you can not skip the random factor.

All these aspects are described in rules which are not complicated.

Among the four scenarios it is introductory scenario - attack of Rosen’s IV corps on alder grove. This is the perfect introduction to a large battle. Players have limited forces and learn basic
rules and characteristics of the terrain. Thanks to this, the experience gained can be used in the course of the scenario for the entire battle.

Game mechanics based on random activations. However, the proper marker set reflects a better command structure of the army of Field Marshal Dybicz. Moreover, this solution provides an exciting game in which each side can take the initiative to surprise the enemy.

Three types of weapons: infantry, cavalry and artillery act according to the common rules, but each of them has its own characteristics. Success on the battlefield provides the appropriate use of the advantages of all kinds of weapons at the right moment. This is obviously the goal pursued by both players. Coordination of their own troops, and respond to your opponent moves makes Battle of Grochow a challenging game, even for experienced players.

Mag-O-Mag features an innovative vertical holder with interchangeable game boards and magnetic game pieces that allows you to play three fun, action-packed games. The games are played in teams, playing one at a time. One teammate must move the guide magnet on the backside of the game board, while the other teammate sees the game magnet move on the front of the board. This teammate must communicate with the one controlling the magnet and tell them how to move the magnet to complete the game challenge without the magnet falling off or going to the wrong spot.


 In the racing game, the object is speed: Which team can complete the course fastest — while making sure you don’t crash!



 In the golf game, the object is precision: How many strokes does the team need to take to reach the hole? Traps await everywhere!



 In the treasure hunt game, players must collect as many gems as possible in a given time. Who can amass the most valuable treasure?


Mag-O-Mag includes cooperative game variations and special rules for two-player games.

name.value: Paw Patrol: Sports Day Challenge Path Game

item.description: Players choose one of three pups (Chase, Marshall, or Skye) and take turns racing along a path. A spinner determines the distance moved. Certain squares along the path earn the player trophies (points), or send a player backwards a short distance. Along the way, players choose to take a longer and safer path, or a shorter path that risks giving their trophies to the player with the least amount. Players that reach the finish line earn an additional trophy on their turn. The game ends when the last pup crosses the finish line.

name.value: Triumph of the Will: Nazi Germany vs. Imperial Japan, 1948

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

This game allows two players to game an alternate history where Germany and Japan have won WWII. Three years after that victory in 1948 they square off against each other for a final battle for world domination. The map of the game joins along the equator to depict the entire world.

Game mechanics recreate dilemmas and challenges inherent in grand-strategic warfare and the issues involved with controlling the entire planet. Movement switches rapidly back and forth between players keeping you fully involved in the game with no long waits between players. In any order you want, you can: enter reinforcements; bring back into play previously eliminated units; move an army, air force, fleet or elite corps on the map via land, sea or air; launch a conventional attack or launch a nuclear attack. Both conventional and nuclear attack options are available to players.

Complexity: Medium
Time Scale: Varies 1yr/turn
Map Scale: Global Area Movement
Unit Scale: Armies/Fleets/Air Forces

In Mexican Standoff, the players — western heroes that they are — aim to take as many tricks as possible during the eleven rounds of the game, in addition to collecting as many points as possible.

Unlike most games, lower-valued cards are worth more as the deck contains fewer of them. The players can challenge each other, as well as the sheriff, to the Mexican standoff. After a duel, only one player is left standing, and this player takes several tricks at the same time. The player who fights a duel at the most appropriate time and collects the largest points — as well as the highest number of special bandit cards — will be the final one standing when the game ends.

link.value: Mexican Standoff: The Black Scorpion Promo Card

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

It's the fun and fast-paced game you love, now featuring your favorite DC Super Hero Girls! Players race to get rid of all their cards by matching a card in their hand with the current card shown on top of the deck and in this version, there's a special wild card with new DC Super Hero Girls rule and two customizable wild cards. Maybe you'll draw the Save the Day card! That lets you make another player immune from penalty cards until another wild card is played. Score points by being the first to get rid of all the cards in your hand. First player or team to 500 wins. When you're down to one card, don't forget to yell "UNO!" Contains 112 cards plus instructions. For 2 to 10 players, ages 7 and older. Easy to pick up, impossible to put down.

Description from the publisher:

Get ready for a thinking player's game. Dogs Night Out Poker School will not only make you think about your plays, but you will have fun leaving your money off the table. Whether you are new to Texas Holdem or a long time player, your're going to gain an understanding of the game that you have never had before. Gambling is not required.

Two complete games! OUT CARD (the more challenging game) and FIVE BALL POKER (the simpler game). Play with friends, teach friends, play solo. No Matter how you choose to play, you will continuously be improving the game.

Out Card
An entertaining, innovative approach using a combination of tools to analyze a poker game. A visual representation of a poker hand makes it easier to see winning possibilities. Numbering Out Cards in priority order is a challenge that will improve your poker game. This game can be played with friends as a challenge or teaching tool, or play solo for individual learning.

5 Ball Poker
Learn to analyze the top current and best potential hands at five different analysis points represented by Pool balls in a street map format. A simple, yet important tool for your poker game, showing the road to the money hand.

Szyfr Pana Twardowskiego is a simple roll and move racing game designed as promotional material by Bydgoszcz City Hall (Polish city).
Game apart from simple roll and move mechanic uses trivia card with questions related to Bydgoszcz (architecture, geography, history, etc).

While seeking to take control of The Nightmare Forest, two of the Alien factions have decided to have a competition at a nearby dairy farm to see who can abduct more of these tasty cow creatures.

Objective:
Players are trying to collect the most cows from the Pasture, which is made up of cards indicating how many cows are in each space. Players take turns peaking at the cards to determine where the most cows are hiding, deviously moving the cows around, and strategically placing their tractor beam cards along their 2 sides of the pasture. Once all the tractor beams are in place, players compare the power value of the beams that intersect on each cow. The player with the higher total power value pulls that cow into their ship. The player who collects the most cows is the winner.

Throw dice and go from water lily leaf to another and a frog shows how the body whirl. Stretching, balancing, jumping and various dynamic conditions are important for the development of the growing child.

Spinner surprise by accelerating or slowing down the going onwards on leaves.

Include: 18 track tiles, die, spinner and four frogs pawns.

This is a small box that contains several tear-off pads of sheets of several types, as well as 48 numbered cards with samples of famous people's handwriting on one side, and three choices as to whom the handwriting is on the opposite side. Also included is a booklet that goes into some detail about how handwriting analysis works, what can (and cannot) be deducted from it, as well as rules for three variants of games that can be played, two of which use the cards included.

FROM THE INSTRUCTIONS: 
Handwriting Analysis Games
In addition to providing insights into your own personality, the forgoing tests may also be given to your friends, with you acting as amateur graphologist and analyzing their handwriting, signature, and doodles.
The tests may also be used as a basis for a game of handwriting analysis. This can be done as follows:

1. Players choose one of the four tests and analyze themselves according to the instructions for that test. They check off the results on the appropriate pad sheet.
2. Players initial their pad sheets and pass them to one player who has been selected as reader.
3. Reader shuffles the sheets and reads off, one by one, each player's personality traits. As each sheet is read, ALL players (except the reader) must attempt to guess whose personality traits are being read off.
4. Each correct guess scores one point, and at the end, the player with the highest point count wins.

Introduction to Famous People Games
(Skip some info on separating the cards initially)
On the face of each card are some lines of writing by a famous person. Underneath these lines, in the lower right hand corner, is a series of numbers. These numbers refer to t he personality traits on YOUR PERSONALITY PROFILE pad. They give you an instant analysis of t he writer of the line.
For instance, in the example above, the writing shows traits 9, 17 and 21. Looking at the YOUR RESPONSIBILITY PROFILE pad, you can see that the writer has his head and heart in balance, possesses a dramatic flair, exaggerates and likes to be noticed.
These personality traits are clues to the identity of the person in question. On t he back of each card you will find three famous names. One of them is the writer of the line on the face of the card. Using the personality clues mentioned above - and your intuition - Try to match the lines with their real writer. Answers will be found on page 24.

Famous People Game #1
IN this game, any number of players may compete in identifying the writers of the lines on the front of the Famous People Cards. The Game is played as follows:
1. The deck is shuffled and each player cuts. The player with the highest card (number in the upper left hand corner) deals.
2. Dealer deals one card at a time to center of the table - handwritten lines up.
3. Players have a maximum of one minute to look at the writing and compare the numbers beneath it to the numbered personality traits on their YOUR RESPONSIBILITY PROFILE pad sheets. This gives them some idea of the writer's personality.
4. After one minute, the dealer turns the card over. On the back are the names of three possible writers of the lines on the other side. Players must pick the name of the real writer, using their knowledge of the of the people involved or simple intuition.
5. Players record their answers on a sheet from the FAMOUS PEOPLE GAME pad. As each card is turned over, they write the LETTER (a, b, or c) of the famous person chosen in the box next to the NUMBER of that card.
6. After all 48 cards have been dealt, The dealer reads the answers.
7. Players check off correct answers in appropriate boxes on their FAMOUS PEOPLE GAME pads. Each check scores one point. Highest point total wins.
NOTE: Game may be played as a form of solitaire, with one player turning over cards and attempting to guess as many of the famous writers as possible.

Famous People Game #2
This is a handwriting game for from two to six people.
Players analyze the writing of other players and compare their own handwriting with samples written by famous people. The game is played in the following manner:
1. Players take a sheet from the YOUR RESPONSIBILITY PROFILE pad. They fill in samples of their handwriting, following the instructions on the sheet. Each player then passes his sheet to the player on his left for analysis.
2. Players analyze the handwriting samples, using the instructions. The sheets are then passed back to their writers - with check marks next to the personality traits revealed in their handwriting. 
3. One player is appointed dealer. He shuffles the deck and deals one card at a time to center of the table - handwritten lines face up.
4. Players compare the numbers in the lower right hand corner of the card with the numbered personality traits checked off on their YOUR RESPONSIBILITY PROFILE pad sheets. The player with the largest number of matching traits claims the card and places it in the table in front of him.
5. In the case of unmatched cards or ties, the card is considered dead and remains unclaimed in the center of the table.
6. After all 48 cards have been dealt, the player who has been able to claim the most cards is the winner. All players then have an opportunity to see which famous people they most resemble.
7. Players turn over their cards revealing three possible famous writers for each card. The dealer then turns to the answer section below and, taking the cards of each player in turn, announces the names of the famous people whose personalities match his.

An unsavoury crime has been committed in Mintsby and you, the amateur sleuth Sherbet Holmes, aided by your dear friend Dr Winegum, are charged with solving the case.
You must move around the randomly generated playing area, search locations and memorise the suspects you encounter.
For, when you have eliminated the innocent, whoever remains, however improbable, must be the culprit.
A glance at your pocket watch shows you only have 12 hours remaining. Come, Winegum, the game is afoot...

The game is a take on a 'find the pairs' memory game. Find the pair of tiles of a suspect to eliminate them from your enquiries.
However, there are also other tiles which can help or hinder your investigation.
And you must solve the case against the clock.
Dice are used to move to and from locations so your choice of where to search may be restricted - fortunately Dr Winegum is there to help you.

Elemintary was an entry in the 2016 Mint Tin Design contest and it did rather well:

2nd place (equal): Best Overall Design
1st place: Best Artwork & Graphic Design
2nd place: Best Written Rules
4th place: Best Theme

name.value: Carry On: Gear Collecting Card Game

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Carry On is a gear collecting card game for the end of the world. Players compete to stash food and weapons, and seek aid from other survivors.

Each player starts with a "stash" of four cards. Each turn you can play a card from your stash. Different cards have different Actions. After an Action resolves, replace the card played with the top card from the Draw Pile. However, most Actions allow you to Replenish your stash in several strategic ways.

Different cards/items have different Actions, or rather different items cause different things within the game to happen. Tools like the Compass and Shovel allow players to search the Draw Pile and Discard Pile for a card to replenish their Stash. Weapons, like the Tactical Knife and Hand Gun let you intimidate opponents into giving you cards.

In addition to Items, there are also other Survivors within the deck that can you help you on your quest for survival gear. The Minimalist allows you to discard additional cards. The Pacifist gets rid of your opponents Weapons. The Anarchist let's you straight up steal from your opponent. And The Generalist allows you to swap out cards with an opponent.

To win, be the first player to collect all three pieces of radioactive protective gear - Hazmat Boots, a Hazmat Hood, and a Hazmat Suit.

The objective of the game is to obtain the maximum income from the factories and to apply the profits by investing in Villas or in the stock market.

In each round the investor:

 Rolls two dice and moves that number of spaces around the board (if the player is using the Spectrum app, he moves the number of spaces accordingly)
 Exports merchandise (if desired)
 Makes all the transactions he want.




The game ends when the time limit (decided by the players) is reached or the deck of cards is empty.

The winner is the investor with the most capital.

Description from the designer:

In these days of recession, it's not that easy to scrape an honest living. But there's always a neighbour’s lawn waiting to be mowed.
Fortunately you have inherited your grandfather’s MowMaster 2000, in it’s day the height of grass removal technology. Unfortunately that day was about 100 years ago and mowing with it now is tricky, due to the machine’s somewhat limited functions.
Mind you don't smash it into those trees, because it'll cost you for repairs and watch out for that dog. Above all try to steer clear of the customers' flower beds and prize vegetables as they get very upset at the sight of beheaded daffodils or mashed marrow.

Mower Mania is a mix of puzzle/strategy (working out best routes through the gardens), resource management (your mower functions) and luck (dice for movement and randomness of garden tile layout).

When you land on a long grass tile, you turn it over to reveal it nicely mowed. Landing on vegetables or flowers, however, results in loss of points (money). Land on a pot, or go too fast into a tree or garden feature, and you'll also sustain damage to your mower.

The amount you earn will be based on how much of the lawn you've successfully mowed (a minimum amount required to progress to the next garden) and how much damage you've caused. You'll then need to pay for mower repairs and to replenish mower functions you used.
.

Mower Mania was an entry in the 2016 Mint Tin Design Contest and did exceptionally well:

1st place: Best Overall Design
1st place: Best Theme
2nd place: Best Artwork & Graphic Design
3rd place: Best Written Rules
Top pick: of Guest Judge, Caroline Berg 
.

Thanks to all those at BoardgameGeek who played the game, and gave feedback and suggestions, during the contest, especially:
John Kean, lelo Arrowsmith. Scott Allen, GreenTea532, Laura Blachek, G. Uitz, Janine Viglietti, Marianne Waage, Benjamin Wack, Andrew Orel, Niklas Hook, Alex Johns, melbards and James Ronald Lo.

item.description:
Import / Export is a role selection game with a passive and active economy driven by player decisions. You have the power to gain over one hundred unique powers by exporting shipments of goods, specializing into a varied tech tree, and unlocking advanced game engines that will be completely unique to each play!

Once your shipments enter the open sea, someone can trigger an Import action, where everyone will hold a silent auction to buy your containers and either allocate them as a future end game investment or an immediate boost to their available actions for specific roles.

The end goal of the game is to have the most credits, which will be a combination of your physical credits, passive credits that were saved as imported goods, plus any bonuses from completed shipments.

item.description:
Gentes is an interesting civilization game with an innovative timing mechanism.

"Gentes" is the Latin plural word for greater groups of human beings (e.g., tribes, nations, people; singular: "gens"). In this game, players take the role of an ancient people who are attempting to develop by building monuments and colonizing or founding new cities in the Mediterranean sea.

The game is played in six rounds, each consisting of two phases: action phase, and tidying up. There are three eras — rounds 1-2, 3-4, 5-6 — with new monument cards entering the game at the beginning of rounds 1, 3 and 5. Each player has a personal player mat with a time track for action markers and sand timer markers. In the action phase of a round, the players take their turns in clockwise order, conducting one action per turn. Each action requires an action marker from the main board that is placed on the time track. Depending on the information on the action marker, you have to also pay some money or take sand timers that are placed on the time track. When you have no free spaces on your time track, you must pass for the remainder of the round. Therefore, the number of actions per player in a single round may vary significantly if, for example, you choose double sand timers instead of two single ones or take action markers that require more money but fewer sand timers. Single sand timers are dropped in the tidying up phase, while double sand timers are flipped to become single sand timer markers and stay for another round. The actions are:


 Buy new cards from the common display
 Build monuments (playing cards from your hand to your personal display for victory points and new options)
 Train/Educate your people
 Build/found cities
 Take money


To play a card, you must meet the requirements printed on that card, such as having specific persons on your personal board (e.g., two priests and four soldiers). These requirements are why training — i.e., getting specific people — is important, but that is not that easy because there are six different types of people — three on the left and three on the right side of your personal player board — and you have only six spaces in total for the two types in the same line. If you have three merchants, for example, you move your marker for counting merchants three spaces toward the side of the soldiers and thus you have only three spaces left for soldiers. By educating a fourth soldier and moving your soldier marker forward to its fourth space, you automatically lose one merchant because that marker is pushed back to its second space.

It is crucial to generate additional actions by using the specific functions of monuments in your display and cities you have built. Cities are expensive, but they create benefits at the end of each round or provide new options for taking an action without acquiring an action marker, gaining only a sand timer marker instead.

Try to have a steady income to avoid wasting actions to take money. Pay attention to the display of common cards, which is new in every single game, because the monument cards are shuffled randomly within the decks of eras I, II and III. Collect identical achievement symbols on the cards to benefit from the increasing victory points for a series of symbols. Build cities to enlarge your options!

item.description:
Plunder! is a fast-paced card game with a lot of "take that" action. Your goal is to steal treasures and pirate crew members from your fellow pirates by playing cards to attack other players and to defend yourself from attacks.

The game has a simple card-playing mechanic at its core, but outside of your turn you can play reaction cards. These influence cards played by other players. Play them at the right time, so you can benefit from the other pirates' actions!

item.description:
Otto the Octopus is a tile laying game for 1 to 4 players
Players take it in turn to score points by extending and completing Otto's arms, whilst also laying other sea creature tiles for various bonuses and effects.

.
This was an entry in the 2016 Children's Game PnP Contest
and Otto did very well:

1st place: Best Game for Early Elementary School Children
1st place: Best Matching/Pattern Game
1st place: Best Strategy Game

and

link.value: Children's Game Print and Play Contest

item.description:
Two tradesmen vye for business on ladders of ever increasing height.

Play cards to expand your ladder and score points, or to hinder your opponent.

A card can only be played if the number of spots on its edge matches the card that it joins.
A card is placed so that it either joins the top card of a ladder or overlaps it half way. Some cards may be rotated before being placed and those with creatures on have special actions.

.
Ladders was an entry in the 2016 18 Card Microgame Contest

name.value: Hikari to Yami to (光と闇と)

item.description:
The team-based social deduction game Spy King includes three royal families as well as a family of spies who wants to defeat the royals. If the spies defeat all the kings, they win; if the spies are defeated, then the family with the highest value wins.

A moderator is needed to play Spy King, but this player can also be part of a family.

link.value: Ryota Miyagawa (宮川 リョウタ)
Rommel Games (ロンメルゲームズ)

item.description: In this exciting tower building game, players take turns rolling the dice to determine what pieces will be added. The player who makes the tower fall loses the game! Crafted from sustainably forested beechwood, this game is suitable for children over 3 years old, but is fun for the whole family!

item.description: Battle Yahtzee: Deadpool mashes up the irreverent Marvel antihero with a dice game competition that includes custom dice, a custom game board, and score sheet.

name.value: Land of Medievals The Card Game

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Land of Medievals is a Medieval Fantasy card board game with mechanics such as combat, dice rolling and improvement cards.

Fight against fantastic creatures and opponent players, siege enemy castles and become the one and only King of the Land.

Inspired by ancient mythologies the game offers a unique gameplay, you will need to earn Army Units and Improvement cards for your faction, kill creatures at the outside encounters and make intelligent strategies using your cards to defeat opponent players.

name.value: Les bâtisseurs de la tour de Babylon

item.description:
Babylon Tower Builders is an abstract, 3D strategy game. Players take turns building a common structure. The object for each player is to position their nobles to score the most points at game's end, with players scoring based on having a majority of nobles per level.

The game includes a real-time play variant.
